awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Adsorption and Photochemical Transformations of Arsenic and Selenium Species by Natural Organic Matter-Coated Magnetic Nano-sized Iron Oxide Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported jointly by the Chemistry Division's Environmental Chemical Sciences Program and the Environmental Engineering Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems. The collaborative study involves Professors Kevin E. O'Shea and Yong Cai from Florida International University and Professor Dionysios D. Dionysiou from University of Cincinnati. Together with their students, the faculty members seek to develop an environmentally-friendly approach to purifying water. Water contamination by highly toxic arsenic (As) and selenium (Se) is a serious threat to the environment.  This has affected the health of hundreds of millions of humans globally. The approach is to coat magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles with natural organic matter (NOM). The coated nanoparticles can strongly bind arsenic and selenium and can convert them to less toxic forms upon solar irradiation. The magnetic nanoparticles carrying the arsenic and selenium are later removed from the contaminated water with a magnet. Overall, the research activities are expected to strengthen co-operation among the local community, educational institutes, and investigators. The
broader societal impacts of this research include enhancing sustainable development. The knowledge obtained from these studies guides the development of new water treatment methodologies using environmentally-friendly materials. Application of these insights may accelerate the implementation of related technologies in addressing environmental problems, as well as advance the understanding of the interaction of natural organic matter and metals to determine their fate, transport and bioavailability.  The research plan emphasizes participation of persons from underrepresented groups. It also includes a high school outreach program with local schools to educate the students on water quality and water contamination issues.

The project seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of the molecular interactions of As and Se species with fractionated NOM and the subsequent NOM-photosensitized redox transformations of As and Se.  Specific trapping or quenching agents are used to study the roles of individual reactive oxygen species, electron transfer and energy transfer processes in the NOM photosensitized transformations. These fundamental studies guide the selection of the most promising NOM fractions for grafting onto the surface of different sized magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles for the process of interest. The research is expected to aid in the development of strategies for optimizing removal and conversion of toxic metals.  Such a process is is critical to water reuse and treatment.

por.por_cntn:
The project was a collaboration among researchers at Florida International University (FIU) and University of Cincinnati (UC). The primary activities of the project focused on the fundamental understanding of the interactions of arsenic (As) and selenium (Se) with natural organic matter coated magnetite nanoparticles (NOM-MNP), subsequent photosensitized redox transformations, and the development of these sustainable materials for remediation of a variety of naturally occurring toxins and anthropogenic substances. The PI and collaborators conducted a variety of activities to enhance education on contaminants of concern including Se and As, and the role of NOM: (i) offering collaborative research opportunities to student researchers including summer interns, (ii) rigorous and systematic cross-disciplinary training of involved students, (iii) broad dissemination of results through class materials, conference presentations, group meetings, and meetings with collaborators, and (iv) strengthening of research collaboration, including with several research facilities and other departments.  

The primary focus of the FIU team was centered on detailed adsorption studies of the naturally occurring toxins, As and Se, onto NOM-MNP. Material characterization and kinetic modeling studies of NOM-MNP systems led to a better fundamental understanding of the molecular interactions associated with adsorption and the thermodynamic parameters controlling the adsorptive removal of the target substrates.  Among completed goals was the identification and quantification of individual reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the illuminated HA MNP system as well as their roles on the photocatalytic transformation of toxic As(III) to As(V). We also studied the adsorption and potential application of HA MNP for removal of strontium (Sr), problematic organo-arsenic compounds (monomethylarsonic acid and dimethylarsenic acid), phosphate, glyphosate, and a model cationic dye. A PARAFAC model was also developed by the UC team to obtain the unique characteristics of each NOM fraction obtained previously based on the molecular weight cut off. Adsorption of Se(IV) by NOM-MNP that was synthesized by using the fractionated NOM was specifically characterized by FTIR as compared to fluorescence method.

This collaborative study can have strong societal impacts raising the awareness of Ar and Se contamination holds paramount importance as raising awareness for other naturally occurring and anthropogenic contaminants. We believe that a comprehensive characterization of NOM and the molecular interactions with toxins/pollutants provided in this study will enable us to have a deeper understanding of the interaction among these constituents broadly present in many environmental systems. The work has significant impact on the human society specially in the developing/underdeveloped countries as the problem of water contamination by a variety of substrates, notably arsenic and selenium have already affected millions of people. The results of the project provide fundamental understanding to inform and educate the scientific community towards potential economic, simple, and environmentally friendly solutions to serious global challenges over the lack of clean water supplies.
